awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Transmission Electron Microscope
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is made to Loyola University Chicago (LUC) to purchase a Transmission Electron
Microscope (TEM) in support of research, teaching, and outreach. This equipment will be used
by LUC researchers as well as graduate and undergraduate students in STEM fields. Through
didactic courses and research mentorship, over 100 LUC undergraduate students will gain
valuable training on this machine annually. Two undergraduate courses at LUC will utilize the
TEM as will two courses at neighboring undergraduate institutions. The TEM will have the
greatest impact on high school students engaged in summer research at LUC. Each year, LUC
investigators host 40+ aspiring scientists from Chicago area high schools. This high school
research experience will include training and hands-on exploration using the TEM. Thus, the
TEM will promote student training both at LUC and beyond.

This TEM enhances research at all levels. It enables imaging, sizing, and elemental mapping of
samples for a diverse ensemble of scientific fields ranging from biology to materials chemistry to
environmental sustainability. Representative examples include imaging of bacteriophages, the
cellular structural stability of malaria parasites, microscopic structures of lizard scales, bacterial
biofilm formation, cartilage and bone formation in fish embryos, and peripheral nervous system
structure. Furthermore, this machine can examine the chemistry that occurs at the surface of
prototypical small molecule organic semiconductors as well as element-specific measurements
of metal accumulation in living tissue. Thus, the TEM instrument will stimulate the productivity of
the existing research projects as well as train the next generation of scientists.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The award facilitating the purchase of a Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM) at Loyola University Chicago (LUC) promoted research, teaching, and outreach. The machine was utilized by numerous PI lab students as part of both undergraduate and Masters research. For instance, the TEM facilitated the exploration of structures in the model organism Drosophila melanogaster, infection of cells by the malaria parasite Plasmodium berghi, visualization of the morphology of bacterial isolates, and the discovery and characterization of new bacteriophages. This TEM work directly contributed to four MS students’ thesis research, their presentation of this work at local and national conferences, and forthcoming manuscripts. Additionally, the TEM was instrumental in promoting hands-on research training for undergraduates at LUC through three different courses, including a newly designed course-based undergraduate research experience (CURE) course. In this course, undergraduates visualized bacterial isolates which informed their further investigation and characterization of these isolates. Lastly, outreach activities with area Chicago Public Schools introduced high school students to microscopy, enabling them to visualize microorganisms and cell structures. Moreover, ongoing collaborations with primarily undergraduate-serving institutions provide this resource for their students’ training. In summary, the acquisition of this equipment progressed research across domains of life science at LUC while also providing high school, undergraduate, and graduate students with training in cutting-edge technologies.
